text.text_translated:
A new idea is starting. It is called 'buy nothing'. This idea fights against consumerism. Consumerism is when people buy too many things.
It started in Canada in the early 1990s. Then it went to the US.
In the US, people said 'no' to buying too much. They said 'no' to using too much money. This was on Black Friday and Cyber Monday. These days are after Thanksgiving.
On Buy Nothing Day, people make different protests. They cut their credit cards.
All year, Buy Nothing groups organise swapping things. They also organise fixing things. These are things people already have.

feedback.feedback: PASS: The text successfully meets all CEFR A2 readability standards. It maintains factual integrity, preserves the core meaning, and adheres to the A2 linguistic requirements. The MeaningBERT score of 0.8245 and BERTScore of 0.9173 confirm strong fidelity to the original content. The CEFR classifier correctly identified the text as A2. Vocabulary is appropriate, with 'consumerism' being clearly defined in simple A2 terms. Sentence structures are short and direct, using only basic A1/A2 connectors like 'and', 'then', and 'also'. No complex grammatical structures or advanced vocabulary were detected.

best_attempt.text_translated:
A new idea is starting. It is called 'buy nothing'. This idea fights against consumerism. Consumerism is when people buy too many things.
It started in Canada in the early 1990s. Then it went to the US.
In the US, people said 'no' to buying too much. They said 'no' to using too much money. This was on Black Friday and Cyber Monday. These days are after Thanksgiving.
On Buy Nothing Day, people make different protests. They cut their credit cards.
All year, Buy Nothing groups organise swapping things. They also organise fixing things. These are things people already have.
